questions.neutral: Feel like a slow night to you?

hobby.message: Origami help keep the noise out?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Feels slow, sure. Origami passes the time.
Papereasier than people here.
Hard to fold much latelywith all these system challenges.
Yeah. Imostly keep to myself.
Origami keeps me occupied. Complex patterns, not just paper cranes.
This week, interruptions all day since the BCI rituals started.
Folding feels clumsy now.
It does. The cityis out of sync lately.
I make origami modelsgeometry helps me unwind after work.
People keep barging in, asking about Halden's diary or block meetings.
Hard to focus, even basic folds take longer.
Never used to need to hide it.
Quiet, butnot restful.
I fold complex origami, mostly tessellated designs, patterns from memory.
It used to clear my head after Directorate shifts.
Recently, everyone's obsessed with Halden's challenges so folding gets interrupted a lot.
Last night my pattern was crooked. I couldn't concentrate with all the noise.
I wish something familiarwould stay just mine.
Some days, the only straight line I see is in paper.
Seems slow, but my mind's restless lately.
I do origami. Not just simple figuresbut complex tessellations, modular stuff. Been folding since I was a kid.
It helps when my thoughts spiral, especially now that the Directorate keeps sidelining me.
Usually I fold in the corridor, though people think it's pointless.
These BCI ritual challenges—you know, Halden's posthumous games—turned everything into a group performance.
People ask me to fold origami for luck or decode diary clues in shape patterns.
Half the block thinks origami is secret codethey watch me fold like I'm testing them.
Honestlyit's the one thing I still hope is only mine.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still fold paper, when I have time.
Harder now with all these new neighborhood meetings.
Feels like everyone’s watching. Not worth drawing attention.
I keep it simple. Less to explain.
People ask too many questions since the system change.
Still using origami. Quiet hobby, mostly.
Strange how even that got harder after the diary challenges started.
Too many people lingering, looking for clues in everything.
Folding helps focus, but now I hide it when neighbors visit.
Never thought my creased papers would feel like secrets.
The whole building feels suspicious, honestly.
Origami’s still my thing. Helps settle my thoughts.
It’s changed, though, since the BCI went odd.
Usually fold tessellations, but interruptions are constant now.
Lately, neighbors ask if my models hold system clues.
I’m careful not to be seen working on anything intricate.
Work’s already a mess. I like this to stay mine.
Finding quiet to fold is getting tricky.
Yeah. Origami’s still my best defense from spiraling out.
Helps keep my hands moving when my head’s in knots.
Used to finish really complex models. Now people keep barging in.
Halden’s diary rituals made everyone paranoid about hidden messages.
Someone borrowed one of my cranes to check for codes last week.
Feels strange, folding something that used to mean calm.
Work pushes us into challenges, but I just want quiet.
It’s odd, missing the silence of folding more than anything.
Always was my shield, since I started as a kid in Zimra Block.
Folding’s how I process—follow steps, make order where there wasn’t any.
Lately, even that gets invaded. Neighbors crowd the window hoping for clues.
After Halden’s entries leaked, someone searched my paper for signals.
Had to explain I don’t hide codes. Just patterns to keep my thoughts still.
Last Sunday, the laundry corridor was so loud, I tore the grid twice.
Never thought system chaos would unravel my quiet habits.
My score’s too low now to join the challenge groups anyway.
This city, Alex, it makes you question what’s safe to do alone.
